column4: Howdy, I was wondering if someone could maybe help me with a weirdo problem. My ISP uses some kind of custom settings... I don't know what it is exacly, but internet basically works after about 3 minutes of inactivity, when I plug it into my stationary computer. On my laptop however, it does not work. My best guess is that some DHCP setting needs longer timeout. Could someone all knowning point me to the right direction?
is this dsl?
ehternet jack from the wall.
ok.. is this in your house or a business setting?
house.
other people in the house have the same problem. After connecting jack to computer it take a few minutes to connect. This time it doesn't work though. :/
well.. that jack in the wall goes someplace else in the house which interfaces to the cable line or phone line for internet access.. and has an internet "modem" attached.
that modem is for cable internet or DSL.. do you know which?
I'm from sweden, we don't have DSL. Everyone has ethernet everywhere! No modems...
the connection is basically silent for a while, and then it starts to talk back.

wow.. so it must come in via fiber or something.. well. I really don't know I'm sorry to say.. you might ask your ISP about that .. if others are having the same problems then it might be their issue and not yours
their's meaning the ISP
well, thanks anyway. I'm sure they are just doing something "clever". You don't happen to know if there is a DHCP ip aquisition timeout setting and how one would go about changing that value?
I don't ... however you might try using network manager and "disconnect" the network.. pause.. then reconnect and the computer will request an IP again.
that's how i used to "fix it" before!
ifup / ifdown
but now it doesn't work. Oh well. I'll google "internet not working" and die of old age. :)
LOL!  what happens if your machine is off.. plugged into the network and is turned back on.. if it works immediately then it's a strange issue..

no it would still take 3 minutes. Of course I had a router at some point and then everything would work right away, because it would hold the connection. It had an accident involving a plant and a lot of swearing so it's out of commision now.
does it happen when more than one machine is plugged into the network in the house at the same time? does it happen if only one machine is plugged in ?
it happens always, and there's only one jack so i'll go with "one machine".
then you only have 3 choices.. reconnect the way you have been.. google ubuntu dhcp auto refresh timing or something.. or get a new router ..
I'm going to google until I get gray hair, then I'll consider getting a router. :D
thanks.
